revisions.rev:
{{Politics of South Sudan}} The '''foreign relations of South Sudan''' are the relations between the [[South Sudan|Republic of South Sudan]] and [[sovereign state]]s and international organisations. The establishment of the relationships followed the formation of the South Sudanese state on 9 July 2011. [[Sudan]] became the first state in the world to recognise South Sudan. ==Foreign policy== In the immediate aftermath of the country's independence, South Sudan's foreign policy prerogative was seen as a challenge in the quest to balance relations between the [[West]], other [[Africa]]n states and the [[Arab world|Arab states]].{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-07/11/c_13976792.htm |title=News analysis: South Sudan needs equation on external relations to satisfy all parties |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2011-07-11 |accessdate=2011-09-16}} Since independence, South Sudan has sought to shed its reliance on North Sudan, reportedly planning to introduce the [[Swahili language]] and orient itself toward [[East Africa]].{{cite news|url=http://www.coastweek.com/kenxin_110805_04.htm|agency=Coastweek|date=5 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011|title=South Sudanese still in Kenya despite new state}}{{cite news|url=http://thecitizen.co.tz/news/55-east-african-news/12784-south-sudan-free-to-join-the-eac.html|agency=The Citizen|date=12 July 2011|accessdate=12 July 2011|title=South Sudan 'free to join the EAC'}}{{cite news|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate+News/RVR+targets+planned+Uganda+Sudan+railway+line/-/539550/1213656/-/n67o0bz/-/|agency=Business Daily|title=RVR targets planned Uganda-Sudan railway line|first=Allan|last=Odhiambo|date=5 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011}} ==Chronology of relations== Many states have recognised South Sudan upon independence, or announced planning to do so. Sudan was the first to do so on 8 July 2011, 1 day prior to independence. Four other states followed suit on 8 July. Over 25 countries had recognised the country on 9 July, including all permanent members of the [[United Nations Security Council]].{{cite web |url=http://www.20minutes.fr/ledirect/755873/france-reconnait-sud-soudan |title=La France reconnaÃ®t le Sud-Soudan |accessdate=9 July 2011 |publisher=20 Minutes |author=Reuters |language=French}}{{cite web|title=South Sudan: The birth of a nation|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=628419182|date=9 July 2011|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]}}{{cite web|title=ÐÐ¾Ð·Ð´ÑÐ°Ð²Ð¸ÑÐµÐ»ÑÐ½Ð¾Ðµ Ð¿Ð¾ÑÐ»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ ÐÑÐµÐ·Ð¸Ð´ÐµÐ½ÑÑ Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð®Ð¶Ð½ÑÐ¹ Ð¡ÑÐ´Ð°Ð½ Ð¡Ð°Ð»ÑÐ²Ð°ÑÐ¾ÑÐµ ÐÐ¸Ð¸ÑÑ ÐÐ°ÑÑÐ´Ð¸ÑÑ|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/news/11882|date=9 July 2011|publisher=[[President of Russia]]|language=Russian}}{{cite web|url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/texttrans/2011/07/20110709070453tegdirb0.1807454.html?CP.rss=true#axzz1RblFU2Ag |title=Obama on U.S. Recognition of South Sudanâs Independence | IIP Digital |publisher=Iipdigital.usembassy.gov |date= |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite web|title=China recognizes independence of South Sudan|url=http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/china/9 July 2011/content_12869896.htm|date=9 July 2011|publisher=[[China Daily]]}} ;United Nations member states {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! First state to recognise South Sudan.{{cite news|title=North Sudan recognizes independence of South Sudan|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/9618667-north-sudan-recognizes-independence-of-south-sudan|accessdate=8 July 2011|newspaper=Allvoices}}{{cite news|title=Sudan recognises independence of oil-rich south |url=http://www.sharenet.co.za/news/Sudan_recognises_independence_of_oilrich_south/d651620e6c839e23448e0683d3d41708|quote= Sudan became the '''first''' state to recognise the independence of its oil-producing south...|accessdate=8 July 2011}} |- | {{TLS}} || {{dts|format=dmy|13 October 2011}}http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=5896&lang=en&n=1 || {{cite news|title=PR timorense saÃºda independÃªncia |url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/pt_pt/noticias/africa/2011/6/28/timorense-sauda-independencia,48db0487-82e5-4ae9-9f50-6f913b3e54b3.html}} |- | {{UK}} || {{dts|format=dmy|9 July 2011}} || {{flagu|Commonwealth of Nations}} member
{{flagdeco|UN}} UNSC permanent member {{cite web|title=South Sudan: The birth of a nation|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=628419182|date=9 July 2011|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/news/south-sudan-becomes-independent/ |title=South Sudan becomes independent |publisher=Number10 |date=2011-07-09 |accessdate=2011-09-16}} |- | {{USA}} || {{dts|format=dmy|9 July 2011}}http://southsudan.usembassy.gov/consulate-news/pr07132011.html || {{flagdeco|UN}} UNSC permanent member {{cite web|url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/texttrans/2011/07/20110709070453tegdirb0.1807454.html?CP.rss=true#axzz1RblFU2Ag |title=Obama on U.S. Recognition of South Sudanâs Independence | IIP Digital |publisher=Iipdigital.usembassy.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-07-09}} |} ;Non-members of the UN {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country !! Date of [[Diplomatic recognition|recognition]] !! Relations established !! Notes |- | {{SADR}} || {{dts|format=dmy|2011|7|9}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/establishment-diplomatic-relations-between-republic-south-sudan-and-saharawi-republic |title=Establishment of diplomatic relations between Republic of South Sudan and Saharawi Republic | Sahara Press Service |publisher=Spsrasd.info |date= |accessdate=2011-09-16}}||[[File:Flag African Union.svg|border|20px]] [[African Union]] (AU) member {{cite news|title=Saharawi Republic formally recognizes Republic of South Sudan|url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/saharawi-republic-formally-recognizes-republic-south-sudan|date=9 July 2011|accessdate=10 July 2011|publisher=Sahara Press Service}} |} ==Representation in South Sudan== The [[United States]] upgraded its Juba consulate to an embassy on 9 July 2011.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.state.gov/index.php/site/entry/recognizes_south_sudan|title=U.S. Recognizes Republic of South Sudan As Sovereign, Independent State|publisher=United States Department of State|accessdate=9 July 2011}}, as did [[France]].{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/south-sudan_7540/index.html |title=France-Diplomatie - South Sudan |publisher=Diplomatie.gouv.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-09-16}} Also Sudan has announced that it plans to open an embassy in [[Juba, South Sudan|Juba]], upon independence,[http://allafrica.com/stories/201103211204.html "Khartoum Opens Embassy in Juba as South Approaches Separation"] AllAfrica.com 19 March 2011. Retrieved 5 April 2011. while [[Egypt]] has announced it intends to convert its existing consulate in Juba into a full embassy.[http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=214036 "Egypt says will recognize new South Sudan state"] ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' 27 March 2011. Retrieved 5 April 2011.{{cite news |title=Egypt second country to recognize South Sudan |author=Almasry Alyoum Staff |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/473364 |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date= 1 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} The [[United Kingdom]] has opened an embassy in South Sudan, as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/content/en/contact/sub-sahara-africa/juba-british-embassy |title=South Sudan, Juba, British Embassy |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |date=2009-01-18 |accessdate=2011-09-16}} On 16th September 2011, the ambassadors of the United Kingdom and Norway presented their credentials, the first to do so.{{cite news|url=http://www.goss-online.org/magnoliaPublic/en/news.html#President Kiir receives credentials of UK and Norway ambassadors |title=President Kiir receives credentials of UK and Norway ambassadors |publisher=Government of the Republic of South Sudan |date=16 September 2011 |accessdate=18 September 2011}}. Credentials were presented on 15th November of that year by Chinese, German and Kenyan ambassadors.http://www.goss-online.org/magnoliaPublic/en/news.html#President Kiir receives credentials of three ambassadors According to [[India]]n officials, [[New Delhi]] will upgrade its consulate in Juba to an embassy and appoint an [[ambassador]] to South Sudan.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2215972.ece|title=The Hindu : News/National: India extends diplomatic recognition to South Sudan|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=10 July 2011|location=Chennai, India|date=10 July 2011}} ===International organisations=== South Sudan became a member of the [[United Nations]] on 14 July 2011.{{cite web|title=UN welcomes South Sudan as 193rd Member State|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=39034&Cr=South+Sudan&Cr1=|accessdate=14 July 2011|date=14 July 2011|publisher=United Nations News Service}} It joined the [[African Union]] on 27 July 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/east/South-Sudan-Becomes-African-Unions-54th-Member-126320433.html|title=South Sudan Becomes African Union's 54th Member |publisher=Voice of America News |date=28 July 2011 |accessdate=28 July 2011}} South Sudan has also either applied or is in the process of applying to the [[Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa]],{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/South-Sudan-avails-new-foreign,39637|agency=Sudan Tribune|title=South Sudan avails new foreign policy, to open 54 embassies|date=25 July 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011}} the [[Commonwealth of Nations]],{{cite news |url = http://talkofsudan.com/sudan/item/9001-south-sudan-launches-bid-to-join-commonwealth |agency=Talk of Sudan |date = 8 July 2011 |accessdate =9 July 2011 |title = South Sudan Launches Bid to Join Commonwealth}} the [[East African Community]],{{cite news|url=http://www.busiweek.com/11/editorial/editorial/1316-welcome-south-sudan-to-eac|agency=East African Business Week|title=Welcome South Sudan to EAC!|date=10 July 2011|accessdate=10 July 2011}} the [[Intergovernmental Authority on Development]], the [[International Monetary Fund]],{{cite news|url=http://www.imf.org/external/np/sec/pr/2011/pr11145.htm|agency=International Monetary Fund|title=IMF Receives Membership Application from South Sudan, Seeks Contributions to Technical Assistance Trust Fund to Help New Country|date=20 April 2011|accessdate=10 July 2011}} and the [[World Bank]].{{cite news|url=http://finchannel.com/news_flash/World/90526_World_Bank_Group_Congratulates_People_of_South_Sudan_on_Independence/|agency=The Financial|date=9 July 2011|accessdate=10 July 2011|title=World Bank Group Congratulates People of South Sudan on Independence}} South Sudan has also been assured membership in the [[Arab League]],{{cite news|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=290577&MID=0&PID=0|agency=NOW Lebanon|date=12 July 2011|title=Will South Sudan be a wake-up call for the Arabs?|accessdate=12 July 2011|first=Hussein|last=Ibish}} should it decide to pursue membership, though it could also opt for observer status.{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1055/re10.htm|agency=Al-Ahram|date=7 July 2011|accessdate=8 July 2011|title=Hoping for the best|first=Asmaa|last=El-Husseini}} it may also seek membership in the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]], which has expressed interest in giving South Sudan admission{{cite news|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic_detail.asp?t_id=5480|agency=Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|date=9 July 2011|accessdate=12 July 2011|title=OIC Secretary General Welcomes the Birth of the Republic of South Sudan}} despite not being a majority Muslim state. On 24 July 2011, President [[Salva Kiir]] told the Speaker of the [[East African Legislative Assembly]] that he hoped the EAC will consider expediting South Sudan's accession to the supranational organisation. South Sudan is considered very likely to join the EAC, but an exact timetable for admission has not yet been mooted publicly.{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201107261840.html|agency=allAfrica.com|title=East Africa: South Sudan Ready to Join EAC - Salva Kiir|first=David|last=Muwanga|date=24 July 2011|accessdate=2 August 2011}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; width:100%;" |- ! International organisation !! Status |- | [[File:Flag African Union.svg|border|20px]] [[African Union]] (AU) || The African Union welcomed South Sudan as its 54th member state. |- | {{flag|Arab League}} || The Arab League wishes South Sudan to become a member state. [http://www.elmoudjahid.com/fr/flash-actu/5404 Sud-Soudan : La Ligue arabe reconnaÃ®t le nouvel Etat et souhaite son adhÃ©sion Ã  l'Organisation (In French)] However, South Sudan does not have a majority Arab population and in South Sudan there is strong opposition to joining. [http://www.southsudannewsagency.com/opinion/columnists/the-arab-league-should-know-that-south-sudan-is-not-for-sale The Arab League should know that South Sudan is not for sale] |- | {{flag|East African Community}} (EAC) || South Sudan's membership in the EAC is favoured by all members.{{cite web|url=http://www.busiweek.com/11/editorial/editorial/1316-welcome-south-sudan-to-eac |title=Welcome South Sudan to EAC! |publisher=Busiweek.com |date=2011-07-10 |accessdate=2011-09-16}} |- | {{flag|International Olympic Committee}} (IOC) || A South Sudan committee has yet to apply and might not be able to finish the process in view of the many requirements. South Sudan athletes may be able to compete in the 2012 Olympic games "under other colours".{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/8632832/London-2012-Olympics-South-Sudan-can-compete-at-Games.html|title=London 2012 Olympics: South Sudan 'can compete at Games'|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=12 July 2011|author=R. Rai}} |- | {{flag|United Nations}} (UN) || On July 14th, South Sudan became 193rd UN Member State.{{cite web|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=39034&Cr=South+Sudan&Cr1= |title=UN welcomes South Sudan as 193rd Member State |publisher=Un.org |date=2006-06-28 |accessdate=2011-09-16}} |} ==Individual states== ===Egypt=== {{main|Egypt â South Sudan relations}} [[Essam Sharaf]], Prime Minister of Egypt after the [[Arab Spring]]-inspired [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|revolution]] in 2011 made his first foreign visit to [[Khartoum]] and [[Juba]] in the lead-up to South Sudan's secession.[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1041/eg1.htm AlAhram Weekly - Heading for headwaters] ===India=== {{main|South Sudan â India relations}} ===Israel=== {{main|Israel â South Sudan relations}} Relations between the two states commenced with Israel's recognition of South Sudan a day after its independence[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/10/us-israel-sudan-south-idUSTRE7690PB20110710 Israel recognises South Sudan, offers economic aid] ''Reuters'', July 10, 2011 and South Sudan announcing the following week its intention to establish full diplomatic relations with Israel.{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE76E1EA20110715|title=South Sudan will have relations with Israel-official|publisher=Reuters|date=July 15, 2011|accessdate=15 July 2011}} On 28 July 2011, it was announced that full diplomatic ties had been established between the two countries.{{cite news | url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-announces-full-diplomatic-ties-with-south-sudan-1.375746 | title=Israel announces full diplomatic ties with South Sudan | first=Barak | last=Ravid | newspaper=''[[Haaretz]]'' | date=28 July 2011 | accessdate=28 July 2011 }} This is considered a significant boon to Israel, as Sudan does not have diplomatic relations with Israel and does not recognise Israeli sovereignty. Economic ties show the most potential. As of 23 July 2011, several Israeli companies are already in talks for various business deals. {{cite news | url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4097591,00.html | title=Israeli companies discover South Sudan | work=Money ××××× | date=22 July 2011 | agency=YNetNews | accessdate=23 July 2011 | author=Petersburg, Ofer}} Israel is host to thousands of refugees from South Sudan, who are now ready to return to their native country.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/netanyahu-israel-recognizes-south-sudan-as-independent-state-1.372460 Netanyahu: Israel recognizes South Sudan as independent state] ===Sudan=== {{main|South Sudan â Sudan relations}} Since independence relations with Sudan have been under negotiation. Sudan's President [[Omar al-Bashir]] first announced, in January 2011, that dual citizenship in the North and the South would be allowed,{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12144675 |title=Southern Sudan votes on independence |author=Will Ross |publisher=BBC |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011}} but upon the independence of South Sudan he retracted the offer. He has also suggested an EU-style confederation.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14089843 |title=South Sudan becomes an independent nation |publisher=BBC News |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} ===Uganda=== {{main|South Sudan â Uganda relations}} Prior to independence relations between the two states were fostered through cultural contacts such as the presence of South Sudanese students in Uganda. As independence approaches the two states started to enhance their economic ties. However, the [[Lord's Resistance Army]]'s presence in South Sudan was a stumbling block. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Portal|South Sudan}} {{Foreign relations of South Sudan}} {{South Sudan topics}} [[Category:Foreign relations of South Sudan| ]] [[Category:Foreign relations by country|South Sudan]] [[it:Relazioni internazionali del Sudan del Sud]] [[hu:DÃ©l-SzudÃ¡n kÃ¼lkapcsolatai]] [[ru:ÐÐ½ÐµÑÐ½ÑÑ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»Ð¸ÑÐ¸ÐºÐ° Ð®Ð¶Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð¡ÑÐ´Ð°Ð½Ð°]] [[vi:Quan há» Ngoáº¡i giao cá»§a Nam Sudan]]
